subject: Re: [junit] failSame,. etc. will be public?
msgSnippet: #: by Elliotte Harold s words the mind was *winged* :# ... what would be the junit meaning? ... I thought java used the assertion idea from Eiffel. ... I see.
messageBody:
#: by Elliotte Harold's words the mind was *winged* :#
> The word "assertion" has several meaning depending on context. JUnit's
> use of the word is not the use of the word being expressed in the
> JavaDoc or the Java language Specification.
>

what would be the junit meaning?

> It's similar to how the word "interface" in some contexts refers to a
> generic OOP principle and in some other contexts refers to a specific
> Java language construct identified by a keyword.
>
> Both JUnit assertions and Java assertions derive from the generic
> programming practice of making assertions in code as done with macros in
> C, but they are implemented differently; and they aren't the same thing.
>

I thought java used the assertion idea from Eiffel.

>> While testing we are almost always talking about assertion. I agree that using an Error, instead of
>> an exception may be just a little wrong.
>> I am not sure what do you mean by <<right to the line that failed>>. Any Throwable will do just the
>> same.
>
> But where's the line that failed for a JUnit test? Suppose I have this
> method:
>
> public static void main(String[] args) {
>
> assert 2 == 3;
> System.out.println("Hello");
> }
>
> Here's the stack trace:
>
> Exception in thread "main" java.lang.AssertionError
> at Test.main(Test.java:10)
>
> Now let's change that method to use assertEquals instead:
>
> public static void main(String[] args) {
>
> junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(2, 3);
> System.out.println("Hello");
> }
>
> Here's the stack trace now:
>
> Exception in thread "main" junit.framework.AssertionFailedError:
> expected:<2> but was:<3>
> at junit.framework.Assert.fail(Assert.java:47)
> at junit.framework.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:282)
> at junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:64)
> at junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:201)
> at junit.framework.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:207)
> at Test.main(Test.java:10)
>
>
> If I assertEquals(x, y), then the top line of the stack trace when the
> assertion fails is not assertEquals(). That will appear several lines
> down. The top of the stack trace will be the actual throw line in the
> Assert class. By contrast if I "assert x == y" and x is not equal to y,
> then that is the line that appears at the top of the stack trace.
>

I see. Probably a good tool will be able to filter the unnecessary infos there.

:alex |.::the_mindstorm::.|
